subtitle.text: In the last video,
I talked all about the window object
and how you can pretty much just ignore it completely.
And in this video,
we wanna talk about the document object,
which is incredibly useful all across programming
in the browser.
So to see exactly what this document object is,
let's just console.log out document,
and we just type in document.
This is exactly the same as if we typed window.document.
They're both the same thing we can just use document though,
or window.document it's going to print the same thing.
As you can see,
it prints out this weird like hashtag document.
And when we open this up,
you're gonna see document
is essentially just all of the HTML for our page.
You can see this is the exact HTML of our entire page from this index.html here.
So it's printing out the HTML of our page
and that's really useful because the document allows us to get elements
from our HTML.
It allows us to modify our HTML,
create new elements to add into our HTML.
It's really the way you interact with the HTML of your page.
So for example, if we wanna get the body,
we could say document.body,
and this is going to give us that body element of our document.
We could also get for example, document.documentElement,
and this is going to give us just the HTML portion of our document.
You can notice when we had just document here,
it also gave us this doc type at the top,
but if we just wanna get the HTML element and everything inside of it,
that's what document.documentElement is used for it.
Now, I also mentioned that you can create elements
with document.createElement.
So let's just come in here
and we're gonna create a new element
and we're gonna set it equal to document.createElement.
And this is a function.
And all you do is pass the name of the tag.
So you can create, for example, a div
or you can create a span, whatever you want to create.
We'll just create a span here, for example.
And then we can take our element.
And let's just set the inner HTML to,
"Hello World!"
So let's just save this,
and we'll see what happens in our document.
And you can see, nothing really happened.
That's because we created the element,
but we never actually added it into the document.
So if we wanna do that, we need to get a reference
to the element that we want to add it to.
So let's just get document.body here.
We can say document.body.appendChild
and just append that element we created.
So we can save this and we should now see it.
There it is, hello world!
Now, you can also use the querySelector and querySelectorAll.
So if we wanna get, for example, just an element with a specific ID,
we can use document.querySelector.
And we can select by ID,
so you can use the hashtag and then the ID of the element.
And if you wanna select multiple elements,
you can use querySelectorAll.
So let's just give an example of that.
Let's just select the body and add an ID to it.
So we'll just give this an ID of "my-body".
And we'll select that using document.querySelector.
We'll say const myBody is equal to document.querySelector.
And we can pass in our ID using hashtag my-body.
So now we can do whatever we want with this element.
We can append children to it, change the inner HTML,
and do all sorts of stuff.
And that's it for this video!
We learned all about document and how to interact with it.
